articles.description:
Added: support an experimental template for YouTube feed üì∫ Demo | Source

Aggregate content from any YouTube channel rss url https://www.youtube.com/feeds/videos.xml?channel_id=<replace_with_channel_id>
Videos are embedded via iframe and loading accelerated by youtube-lite-embed
Ads are reduced thanks to YouTube's policy for embedded videos üôÉ
Works on mobile devices with butter smooth horizontal scroll.
Caveat: the template works only with YouTube content. You cannot mix textual RSS feed or other video sources such as Vimeo.
Changed: Default HTML template meta tag adjusted to match convention
Changed: sources in template data is now ordered by last update timestamp (as opposed to alphabetical)
Thank you @PiyushLosalka
articles.title: v1.11.0

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Marcus Herrmann)
articles.description: Web app accessibility appears difficult because it seems that there is little information on the subject available online. Let‚Äôs take a closer look at the accessible use of framework features, concrete Vue.js traits, as well as community initiatives and vetted patterns.
articles.title: Three Insights I Gained While Researching Vue.js Accessibility

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cassidy Williams)
articles.description: There are two strategies for incrementally building websites that are growing in popularity: Incremental Static Regeneration and Distributed Persistent Rendering. What‚Äôs the difference? Let‚Äôs figure it out.
articles.title: ISR vs DPR: Big Words, Quick Explanation

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: In this article, you‚Äôll get to see some pretty groundbreaking things you can achieve with modern JavaScript grids and discover new ways to augment a data grid to make it engaging, responsive, and accessible. All this will be illustrated using Kendo UI Data Grids and their features.
articles.title: You Can Do That With A JavaScript Data Grid?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Too often dealing with filters can be frustrating. Let‚Äôs get them right. That means never freeze the UI on a single input, provide text input fallback and never auto-scroll users on a single input. Here‚Äôs why.
articles.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Broken Filters

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Michelle Barker)
articles.description: In JavaScript, attaching an event listener to constantly fire a callback on scroll can be performance-intensive. But there is a better way with Intersection Observer.
articles.title: Building A Dynamic Header With Intersection Observer

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Facundo Giuliani)
articles.description: In this article, we‚Äôre taking a closer look at different approaches and strategies on how we can migrate a web application that uses jQuery framework, and start using one of the coolest React frameworks in the market: Next.js.
articles.title: How To Migrate From jQuery To Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: CSS refactoring is not an easy task ‚Äî it needs to be done in a way that doesn't create problems. First we need to analyze the existing codebase, audit CSS codebase health, discover weaknesses, agree on the approach, and convince management to invest time and resources into the process.
articles.title: Refactoring CSS: Introduction (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Todd Libby)
articles.description: Accessibility is often overlooked or bolted on to the end of a project. Let‚Äôs figure out how to implement and advocate for accessibility from the inception of a project to the release or handoff and beyond.
articles.title: Making A Strong Case For Accessibility

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Uma Victor)
articles.description: Even though Vue.js claims to have an approachable minimalist framework that can be incrementally adaptable, it can be a little bit overwhelming when starting as a Vue.js newbie. In this article, we‚Äôre looking at ways to make writing Vue.js a breeze.
articles.title: Tools And Practices To Speed Up The Vue.js Development Process

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Emiliano Cicero)
articles.description: Interactive Components in Figma allows designers to create a component with states (hover, active, clicked, focus) and make it interactive so that every copy of the component will inherit those same interactions by default. Let‚Äôs explore how it can reduce the time and effort needed to create interactions for your mock-ups.
articles.title: An Introduction To Figma Interactive Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Emmanuel Tissera)
articles.description: There is an array of Headless CMSes out there. In this article, we delve into headless CMS features to satisfy your content editors, marketers and yourself as a developer. For the experience headless practitioner, this could be a checklist to see what‚Äôs new out there. For those starting out on their headless journey, this could be a guide on what to look for.
articles.title: How To Choose A Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ahmad Shadeed)
articles.description: In this article, Ahmad Shadeed explains what HSL is, how to use it, and shares some of the useful use-cases and examples that you can use right away in your current projects.
articles.title: Using HSL Colors In CSS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andriy Zapisotskyi)
articles.description: With so many tools and approaches, email still has quite a few pain points, both for developers and email marketers. Email is difficult because it has too many aspects to set and a few instances with no common rules to follow.
articles.title: Email Testing Flow As It Should Be

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ramona Schwering)
articles.description: When writing front-end tests, you‚Äôll find a lot of pitfalls along the way. Let‚Äôs explore common mistakes developers make, and how to avoid them. Testing doesn‚Äôt need to be painful, after all.
articles.title: It‚Äôs A (Front-End Testing) Trap! Six Common Testing Pitfalls And How To Solve Them

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Surma)
articles.description: The web is single-threaded. This makes it increasingly hard to write smooth and responsive apps. Workers have a bad rep, but can be an important and useful tool in any web developer's toolbelt for these kinds of problems. Let‚Äôs get up to speed on Workers on the Web!
articles.title: The State Of Web Workers In 2021

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let‚Äôs welcome July with some fresh desktop wallpapers. Designed by artists and designers from around the world, they are available with and without a calendar. Enjoy!
articles.title: The Many Shades Of July (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (√Åtila Fassina)

articles.title: Breaking Down Bulky Builds With Netlify And Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)

articles.title: Creating Custom Emmet Snippets In VS Code

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Dom Habersack)

articles.title: Creating A Multi-Author Blog With Next.js

articles.title: How To Run A UX Audit For A Major EdTech Platform (Case Study)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Josh Singer)
articles.description: In the dynamic and unpredictable environments in which we work, even the most carefully crafted solutions can have a short shelf life. When we accept that our work is impermanent and our problem-solving abilities are limited, our goal can shift from delivering full solutions to developing tools that empower our users to adaptively design for themselves.
articles.title: The Rise Of Design Thinking As A Problem Solving Strategy

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Iris Lje≈°njanin)
articles.description: Frontend and design are remarkably complex these days. And we have new ones coming up, and we‚Äôd like to kindly welcome you to join in.

However, due to the bad feedback loop resulting from voice assistants can only solve simple user tasks such as setting an alarm or playing music. In order for voice user interfaces to really break through, feedback to the user must be visual, not auditive.

articles.title: Learn the FARM Stack! (FastAPI, React, MongoDB)

articles.title: How to Build a GraphQL Server with Laravel GraphQL and Test It with Postman

articles.author: Eno
articles.description:
Jest Architecture


https://github.com/wscats/jest-architecture
Jest is a Javascript testing framework developed by Facebook. It is a JavaScript library for creating, running and writing tests.
Jest is released as an NPM package and can be installed and run in any JavaScript project. Jest is currently one of the most popular test libraries for the front-end.
In technical terms, testing means checking whether our code meets certain expectations. For example: a function called sum (sum) should return the expected output given some operation result.
There are many types of tests, and you will soon be overwhelmed by the terminology, but the long story short tests fall into three categories:
unit test
Integration Testing
E2E test
In terms of testing, even the simplest code block may confuse beg‚Ä¶
articles.title: Explain the implementation principle of the Jest framework in a simple way

articles.author: Gaurav Maheshwari
articles.description:
Hey Guysüñê!! In this Blog I will tell you about git config command, Git aliases, which allow you to create shortcuts for frequently used Git operations. Becoming familiar with git config and the various Git configuration settings will help you create a powerful, customized Git workflow.
Git Config and Git Aliases
The git config command is a convenience function that is used to set Git configuration values on a global or local project level. These configuration levels correspond to .gitconfig text files.
Mainly there are three config levels 
--local
--global
--system
NOTE: the order of priority for configuration levels is: local, global, system. This means when looking for a configuration value, Git will start at the local level and bubble up to the system level.

Let's First check whether ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Git Config and Git Aliases

articles.author: Aya Bouchiha
articles.description:
Hello, on this amazing day, we'll discuss the 3 most common Javascript selectors. getElementById is used to return an element using his id. If there is no element with the giving id, it returns null.

Aya Bouchiha

querySelector is used to return the first element that matches the giving CSS selector. querySelectorAll is used to return all elements (as a NodeList object) that matche the giving css selector.
Hi
Bonjour
Salam
getElementById: for selecting an element using his Id querySelector: for getting the first element that matches the giving css selector querySelectorAll: for returning as a NodeList object All elements that matche the giving css selector. Happy codding!
articles.title: The 3 most commun DOM selectors

articles.author: Conor Bronsdon
articles.description:
Continuous Delivery isn‚Äôt about how fast you can deliver, it‚Äôs about the outcome your delivery achieves. 
In this week‚Äôs episode of the Dev Interrupted podcast we talk with Bryan Finster, author of 5-minute DevOps, about outcome-based development and why failing small is better than failing fast.
Listen to the full episode







  
  
  Episode Highlights include:



What is Outcome-based Development?
What is the true goal of Continuous Delivery?
Why failing small is better than failing fast.
The most common pitfalls dev teams find when trying to optimize their delivery process.
Join the Dev Interrupted Discord Server


With over 1200 members, the Dev Interrupted Discord Community is the best place for Engineering Leaders to engage in daily conversation. No sales people allowed. Join the community >>
articles.title: Outcome-based Development w/ Bryan Finster

articles.author: Alvaro Montoro
articles.description:
For an English version of this article, visit this other DEV post
El arte y los dibujos CSS ha existido b√°sicamente desde que se creo CSS. Son una manera perfecta de practicar y aprender y son interesantes como retos de programaci√≥n. Pero tienen un gran problema: el arte CSS no es accesible.
En este post no vamos a ver c√≥mo crear dibujos e ilustraciones en CSS (hay muchos de esos posts). En lugar de eso, nos centraremos en consejos y buenas pr√°cticas para hacer que los dibujos CSS sean m√°s accesibles para todos.
Despu√©s de aplicar estas t√©cnicas, tus im√°genes en CSS se llevar√°n mejor con los lectores de pantalla, personas con necesidades espec√≠ficos de colores, gente con trastornos vestibulares o v√©rtigo... y todo sin impactar negativamente tu arte o tu creatividad. Todos ganan.
Para ver u‚Ä¶

articles.author: John Idogun
articles.description:
Motivation


Recently, I was working on the Q and A section of a web application. And the requirements mandated that users should be provided the option of recording questions live in English or any other suppported languages. Not only that, customer support center should have same privilege of responding with live recorded answers. While scurring the web for some solutions, I came across Recording audio in Django model but the response is somehow outdated. I decided to re-implement a working example using the technologies he suggested.
Django
Videojs-record
Ajax
HTML
Bulma CSS
First off, it is assummed you pretty much familiar with Django. Since we'll be using a lot of Ajax and JavaScript, you should have a working knowledge of JavaScript. Bulma CSS will be used for the presentation, thou‚Ä¶
articles.title: Django and Ajax: Building a Django live recording application

articles.author: benjamesdavis
articles.description:
As Brexit trade negotiations were dragging on at the start of the year, a lot of the discourse was focused on perceived inequities in fishing rights. I felt there was a story in the data that needed to be told. Despite having the largest Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of all EU countries, and some of the richest fishing grounds, UK fleets are restricted to quite modest catches.
Initially, I had grand plans to create a sort of ‚Äòflow map‚Äô that would trace the translocation of fish from fishing grounds to the country of landing. The Common Fisheries Policy provides EU states with mutual access to each other's fishing grounds, but sets quotas that are largely based on catch figures from 40 years ago which today seem arbitrary. Earlier this year, the UK government was pushing to reverse this by ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Finding the Story in the EU Fisheries Data

articles.author: pffigueiredo
articles.description:
Introducing Right-to-Left


If you are trying to build an international web platform and you want it to be accessible anywhere in the world, then, RTL (right-to-left) compatibility is not a just a "luxury", it is a real necessity.
This series are obviously being written by someone who is used to see and read things from a LTR (Left-to-Right) perspective his whole life, or else, this wouldn't even make sense, because RTL would just be the standard.
So let's say, you wanna introduce RTL in your web platform, and you have no idea where to start. And so, you start to look around the internet or even ask your colleagues, and you come up to read or hear something like this:
It's just needed to change the direction in the html tag and it will be ready‚Ä¶
Well kinda, but not really.
Yes, it will sol‚Ä¶
articles.title: Right-to-Left in a web platform (1/6)

articles.title: üé¨Awesome Loading Animation HTML & CSS‚ú®

articles.author: NikhilBelide
articles.description:
Interviewer : Can you explain me the concept of Hoisting?
Dev : Sure. Hoisting is a phenomenon in which JavaScript magicallyü§∫ moves the code to the top.
Interviewer :   
Dev : Sure. Gives an example where we can call a function on a line which is before the function initialization.
Interviewer : Hmm.
In the end you wont get the Job.
I too have seen many tutorials, blogs and sites where they mentioned the same. But programming is not magic. There lies a logic. So, lets actually see how actually HOISTING works.
We know that when we run a script, a Global Execution Context (GEC) is created which consists of two phases. Memory creation phase and Execution phases i.e. run phase.
memory creation phase all the magic happens.
As soon as we run a script all the all the variables and functions are ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Hoisting in JavaScript.

articles.author: Giwa Jossy
articles.description:
Every four seconds, this chrome extension replaces images on any webpage I visit, with random pictures of some of my friends and family. 
Totally enjoyed the building process.

...
A fairly solid understanding of the DOM [Document Object Model] goes a long way when building browser extensions, as you would have to do lots of DOM manipulation.
The project folder contains two files; manifest.json and content.js
Project Folder/
manifest.json
content.js
...
manifest.json
{

    "manifest_version": 2,
    "name": "FriendsFX",
    "version": "1.0.1",
    "description": "Converts every image on a webpage to random pictures of some of my friends",
    "content_scripts": [
        {
            "matches": ["<all_urls>"],
            "js": ["content.js"]
        }
    ]

}


Most of the keys in the ‚Ä¶

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: When designing an index, a database or a search engine, you frequently need to compute the union of two sorted sets. When I am not using fancy low-level instructions, I have most commonly computed the union of two sorted sets using the following approach: v1 = first value in input 1 v2 = first value ‚Ä¶ Continue reading Faster sorted array unions by reducing branches
articles.title: Faster sorted array unions by reducing branches

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: We use CRISPR, a state-of-the-art gene editing technique, to edit the genes of live human patients in a clinical trials. A clinical trial has begun regarding an HIV vaccine. If you choose to forgo meat to fight climate change, you may lower your individual‚Äôs lifetime warming contribution by 2 to 4%. Age-related testosterone loss may ‚Ä¶ Continue reading Science and Technology links (July 10th 2021)
articles.title: Science and Technology links (July 10th 2021)

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: JSON is the de facto standard for exchanging data on the Internet. It is relatively simple text format inspired by JavaScript. I say ‚Äúrelatively simple‚Äù because you can read and understand the entire JSON specification in minutes. Though JSON is a concise format, it is also better used over a slow network in compressed mode. ‚Ä¶ Continue reading Compressing JSON: gzip vs zstd
articles.title: Compressing JSON: gzip vs zstd

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: Reportedly, half of us own a smartphone. It is often reported that women or visible minority earn less money. However, ugly people are doing comparatively even more poorly. We have highly efficient and cheap solar panels. However, we must also quickly dispose of them after a few years which leads to trash. Handling an increasing ‚Ä¶ Continue reading Science and Technology links (June 26th 2021)
articles.title: Science and Technology links (June 26th 2021)
